name: esp-idf-extension
description: Develop and debug applications for Espressif chips with ESP-IDF

walkthroughs.title: ESP-IDF Basic Usage Guide
walkthroughs.description: Learn how to configure the ESP-IDF extension and use its basic features in VS Code

steps.title: Introduction to ESP-IDF in VS Code
steps.description: This walkthrough will guide you through configuring the ESP-IDF extension and demonstrate its basic usage in Visual Studio Code.

steps.title: Configuring the ESP-IDF Extension
steps.description:
‚ùó**Linux and MacOS users:** Please install prerequisites first. The process is quick and simple - follow the steps in our [ESP-IDF install documentation](https://docs.espressif.com/projects/esp-idf/en/latest/esp32/get-started/linux-macos-setup.html#step-1-install-prerequisites).

Once ready, let's configure the ESP-IDF extension:

[Configure ESP-IDF Extension](command:espIdf.setup.start)

steps.title: Creating an Example Project
steps.description:
Now, let's create a new project from ESP-IDF examples:

[Show Example Projects](command:espIdf.examples.start)

üí° Explore different examples to find one that suits your needs.

steps.title: Setting Up Your Project
steps.description:
Before building your project, you'll need to configure some essential settings:

1. Configure your target device

[Set Espressif Device Target](command:espIdf.setTarget)
2. Set up project-specific configurations (not needed in our example)
3. Select serial port 

[Select Port to Use](command:espIdf.selectPort)
4. Select flashing method 

[Select Flash Method](command:espIdf.selectFlashMethodAndFlash)

steps.title: Building, Flashing, and Monitoring
steps.description:
Now that your project is configured, let's build the code, flash it to your device, and monitor the output.

You can perform these operations individually or all at once using the 'Build, Flash and Monitor' command.

[Build, Flash and Monitor](command:espIdf.buildFlashMonitor)

steps.title: Additional Resources and UI Exploration
steps.description:
As a next step, we recommend that you go through the Advanced Walkthrough as well.

[Start Advanced Features Guide Walkthrough](command:workbench.action.openWalkthrough?%22espressif.esp-idf-extension%23espIdf.walkthrough.advanced%22)

walkthroughs.title: ESP-IDF Advanced Features Guide
walkthroughs.description: Explore advanced features and tools for ESP-IDF development in VS Code

steps.title: Introduction to Advanced Features
steps.description:
Overview of advanced ESP-IDF development capabilities.

**Prerequisites:**
 - Completed the Basic Usage Guide
 - Basic familiarity with ESP-IDF concepts
 - Have a working ESP-IDF setup
 - Have your development board ready
 - JTAG debugging hardware (for debugging features)

steps.title: Troubleshooting Guide
steps.description:
Learn about common troubleshooting techniques and how to get help when you need it.

Key features:
- Debug logging configuration
- Environment diagnostics
- Log file locations
- Common issues and solutions

[Run Doctor Command](command:espIdf.doctorCommand)

steps.title: SDK Configuration (menuconfig)
steps.description:
Learn how to customize your project's configuration using menuconfig
Key features:
- Component configuration
- Compiler options
- Flash and partition settings
- Serial port parameters

üí° Tip: Use search bar to quickly find settings

steps.title: Debugging Your Application
steps.description:
Learn how to debug your ESP-IDF applications using VS Code

Key features:
- Conditional breakpoints
- Navigating through the code, call stack and threads
- Halting the target manually
- Watching and setting program variables
- Disassembly view
- Sending GDB Commands
- Peripheral Viewer

steps.title: Installing ESP-IDF Components
steps.description:
Learn how to enhance your project with ESP Component Registry and Arduino-ESP32 integration.

- Browse and install ESP components
- Add Arduino-ESP32 as a component
- Create projects from component examples

[Open ESP Component Registry](command:esp.component-manager.ui.show)

steps.title: Application Size Analysis
steps.description:
ESP-IDF Extension provides powerful tools to analyze your application's memory usage, helping you optimize storage allocation. 

[Open Size Analysis](command:espIdf.size)

steps.title: Partition Table Configuration
steps.description:
The Partition Table Editor provides a user-friendly interface to define and modify your ESP32's flash memory layout.
Key features
- Visual partition table editing interface
- Automatic CSV file generation and management
- Direct integration with ESP-IDF build systemReal-time validation of partition configurations

[Open Partition Editor](command:esp.webview.open.partition-table)

steps.title: Unit Testing
steps.description:
Set up and run unit tests for your ESP-IDF projects.

- Configure test environment
- Write and run tests
- Analyze test results

[Open Testing View](command:testing.viewExplorer)

steps.title: Multi-Project Management
steps.description: Learn to efficiently manage multiple ESP-IDF projects in a single workspace.

steps.title: Next Steps
steps.description:
Congratulations! You've learned about essential advanced features of ESP-IDF development.

Next steps:
- Explore additional tools in ESP-IDF documentation
- Join the ESP32 community forum
- Check out example projects

[Visit Our Documentation](https://docs.espressif.com/projects/vscode-esp-idf-extension/en/latest/additionalfeatures.html)

debugPort.description: Port for ESP-IDF Debug Adapter. Default: 43474

logLevel.description: Log Level for ESP-IDF Debug Adapter

enumDescriptions: Auto Mode will execute a OpenOCD Server and Debug Adapter in Visual Studio Code
Manual Mode requires you to run OpenOCD and Debug Adapter separately

env.description: Environments Variables override in Visual Studio Code launched ESP-IDF Debug Adapter

cwd.description: Working directory (cwd) to use when launching gdb. Defaults to the directory of the 'program'

program.description: Path to the program to be launched

gdbAsync.description: Use mi-async mode for communication with GDB. (defaults to true, always true when gdbNonStop is true)

gdbNonStop.description: Use non-stop mode for controlling multiple threads. (defaults to false)

logFile.description: Absolute path to the file to log interaction with gdb

openGdbConsole.description: (UNIX-only) Open a GDB console in your IDE while debugging

initCommands.description: List of GDB commands sent after attaching to target before loading image on target.

initialBreakpoint.description: Initial hardware breakpoint being set as 'thb <value>'. For a value 'app_main' result in 'thb app_main' in initCommands. If user set an empty string '' no initial breakpoint will be set and if let undefined it will use the default 'thb app_main'. Ignored if user defines initCommands argument.

preRunCommands.description: List of GDB commands sent after loading image on target before resuming target.

symbolFileName.description: If specified, a symbol file to load at the given (optional) offset

symbolOffset.description: If symbolFileName is specified, the offset used to load

imageFileName.description: If specified, an image file to load at the given (optional) offset

imageOffset.description: If imageFileName is specified, the offset used to load

type.description: The kind of target debugging to do. This is passed to -target-select (defaults to remote)

parameters.description: Target parameters for the type of target. Normally something like localhost:12345. (defaults to `${host}:${port}`)

connectCommands.description: Commands to execute for target connection. Normally something like [`-target-select extended-remote localhost:3333`]

host.description: Target host to connect to (defaults to 'localhost', ignored if parameters is set)

port.description: Target port to connect to (defaults to value captured by serverPortRegExp, ignored if parameters is set)

cwd.description: Specifies the working directory of server (defaults to the working directory of gdb)

server.description: The executable for the target server to launch (e.g. gdbserver or JLinkGDBServerCLExe) (defaults to gdbserver)

serverParameters.description: Command line arguments passed to server (defaults to --once :0 ${args.program}).

serverPortRegExp.description: Regular expression to extract port from by examinging stdout/err of server. Once server is launched, port will be set to this if port is not set. Defaults to matching a string like 'Listening on port 41551' which is what gdbserver provides. Ignored if port or parameters is set

serverStartupDelay.description: Delay after startup before continuing launch, in milliseconds. If serverPortRegExp is provided, it is the delay after that regexp is seen.

automaticallyKillServer.description: Automatically kill the launched server when client issues a disconnect (default: true)

uart.description: Settings related to displaying UART output in the debug console

serialPort.description: Path to the serial port connected to the UART on the board.

socketPort.description: Target TCP port on the host machine to attach socket to print UART output (defaults to 3456)

baudRate.description: Baud Rate (in bits/s) of the serial port to be opened (defaults to 115200).

characterSize.description: The number of bits in each character of data sent across the serial line (defaults to 8).

parity.description: The type of parity check enabled with the transmitted data (defaults to "none" - no parity bit sent)

stopBits.description: The number of stop bits sent to allow the receiver to detect the end of characters and resynchronize with the character stream (defaults to 1).

handshakingMethod.description: The handshaking method used for flow control across the serial line (defaults to "none" - no handshaking)

eolCharacter.description: The EOL character used to parse the UART output line-by-line (defaults to "LF").

cwd.description: Working directory (cwd) to use when launching gdb. Defaults to the directory of the 'program'

program.description: Path to the program to be debugged

gdbAsync.description: Use mi-async mode for communication with GDB. (defaults to true, always true when gdbNonStop is true)

gdbNonStop.description: Use non-stop mode for controlling multiple threads. (defaults to false)

logFile.description: Absolute path to the file to log interaction with gdb

openGdbConsole.description: (UNIX-only) Open a GDB console in your IDE while debugging

initCommands.description: List of GDB commands sent after attaching to target before loading image on target.

initialBreakpoint.description: Initial hardware breakpoint being set as 'thb <value>'. For a value 'app_main' result in 'thb app_main' in initCommands. If user set an empty string '' no initial breakpoint will be set and if let undefined it will use the default 'thb app_main'. Ignored if user defines initCommands argument.

preRunCommands.description: List of GDB commands sent after loading image on target before resuming target.

symbolFileName.description: If specified, a symbol file to load at the given (optional) offset

symbolOffset.description: If symbolFileName is specified, the offset used to load

imageFileName.description: If specified, an image file to load at the given (optional) offset

imageOffset.description: If imageFileName is specified, the offset used to load

type.description: The kind of target debugging to do. This is passed to -target-select (defaults to remote)

parameters.description: Target parameters for the type of target. Normally something like localhost:12345. (defaults to `${host}:${port}`)

host.description: Target host to connect to (defaults to 'localhost', ignored if parameters is set)

port.description: Target port to connect to (defaults to value captured by serverPortRegExp, ignored if parameters is set)

uart.description: Settings related to displaying UART output in the debug console

serialPort.description: Path to the serial port connected to the UART on the board.

socketPort.description: Target TCP port on the host machine to attach socket to print UART output (defaults to 3456)

baudRate.description: Baud Rate (in bits/s) of the serial port to be opened (defaults to 115200).

characterSize.description: The number of bits in each character of data sent across the serial line (defaults to 8).

parity.description: The type of parity check enabled with the transmitted data (defaults to "none" - no parity bit sent)

stopBits.description: The number of stop bits sent to allow the receiver to detect the end of characters and resynchronize with the character stream (defaults to 1).

handshakingMethod.description: The handshaking method used for flow control across the serial line (defaults to "none" - no handshaking)

eolCharacter.description: The EOL character used to parse the UART output line-by-line (defaults to "LF").

connectCommands.description: Commands to execute for target connection. Normally something like [`-target-select extended-remote localhost:3333`]

configurationSnippets.label: Eclipse CDT GDB Adapter
configurationSnippets.description: A espidf configuration for remote debugging using GDB.

scripts.ci-test: yarn compile && extest setup-and-run './out/ui-test/*-test.js' -u -s test-resources -o testFiles/testWorkspace/.vscode/settings.json -l DEBUG
